final_report.root_cause: MongoDB in pod url-shorten-mongodb-5b6fdb4d8b-b55c8 failed to start because the TLS certificate mounted from Secret 'mongodb-tls' was expired (or not yet valid). The mongod process is configured to require TLS from that secret (mounted at /etc/tls via the pod spec and referenced in the mongod config), detects the certificate as invalid at startup, emits a fatal error ("The provided SSL certificate is expired or not yet valid."), and aborts. The container repeatedly exits (ExitCode 14), producing CrashLoopBackOff. This is a configuration/secret expiry issue that began when the certificate became invalid (i.e., expiration) and therefore started failing at pod restart/startup time.
affected_resources: secret/mongodb-tls (expired TLS certificate mounted into pod)
final_report.evidence_summary: Pod logs show a MongoDB fatal startup error: "The provided SSL certificate is expired or not yet valid." followed by a fatal assertion and abort. kubectl describe / pod status shows the pod mounts a Secret named 'mongodb-tls' at /etc/tls and the container repeatedly terminates (ExitCode 14) with restartCount=7 and CrashLoopBackOff/back-off events. Service metadata and pod labels/ports were inspected and confirmed correct (service selector matches pod label and targetPort/containerPort = 27017), ruling out Service selector/port mismatch. The constellation of log message + mounted secret + container exit code + repeated restarts directly tie the failure to the expired TLS cert in the mounted Secret.
final_report.investigation_summary: Priority-1 investigation (completed) retrieved pod logs and pod description: logs contain explicit TLS validity error and failure stack from mongod; describe shows Secret mount 'mongodb-tls' and repeated CrashLoopBackOff events — diagnosis: expired TLS cert prevented mongod from completing startup. Priority-2 investigation (completed) validated the Kubernetes Service configuration and pod selector/port alignment; the Service is correctly configured and simply selects the crashing pod. Lower-priority tasks (PVC, image/pull, liveness probes) were considered but were not required to explain the concrete startup fatal error seen in logs. No further data was necessary to localize the root cause to the expired certificate mounted via secret 'mongodb-tls'. The remaining recommended remediation steps are rotating/replacing the TLS certificate (update secret), restarting or rolling the deployment so mongod can start with a valid cert, and adding monitoring/automation (e.g., cert-manager, alerting on secret/certificate expiry) to prevent recurrence.
